name: New York State Museum
reviews: We always enjoy visiting the NY State Museum, from the vast selection of exhibits, children’s play/ learning room, cafe & the top floor carousel, there is always more than enough to see & do to capture the interest & attention of my young son & his mom too! We highly recommend visiting here!

I visited with my grandsons ages 2 and3. They enjoyed every minute. The loved the carousel.
They enjoyed the antique fire engines, sesame Street, subway train and Adirondack hall.thete is a hands-on play area with casts of animal tracks and various other play stations which are all hand on.
The 9/11 exhibit was not a good idea. They could not understand why no one would fix the broken fire engine.

Stopping at the visitors desk made the New York State Museum visit, and indeed our Albany visit, a special endeavor. Our greeter gave wonderful advice regarding must-see and must-do venues of the museum given the limited time. Walking through the boroughs of New York City, visiting hunters and trappers abodes, and riding an authentic merry-go-round were just a few of the experiences visitors will enjoy. This is a must see.

This museum is sure to please the family.  There are hands on exhibits for children and interesting presentations for the older set.  For the value...Free admission...you can't go wrong.  Don't miss the carousel on the upper floor, but check for its operating times. There is even convenient parking next to it.

.I have lived in Albany for 30 years and have visited the "State Museum" many times, most recently today to view several traveling photo exhibits. I realized that I have never written a review of it before, and it definitely merits a review of the highest excellence. In a state which is known for its political dysfunction (especially of late), they sure did this one right ! This is a very interesting, entertaining and worthwhile museum. It is free ( there is a receptacle for voluntary donations of no more than $5 a family, but no pressure is asserted to contribute). The permanent exhibits on the first floor are very interesting--New York City Metropolis and Adirondack Wilderness; an upper floor has smaller exhibits known as "Windows on New York" , along with a carousel. for which an admission is charged. While you can spend considerable time there, you don't have to commit a large chunk of time, in that you can get an appreciation of the exhibits through a leisurely stroll. It doesn’t overpower you or overwhelm you, but is certainly filled with much to see, very well presented.   They also have periodic, traveling exhibits of interest. They have an adjacent parking lot for which there may be a fee, at least on weekdays, not sure about weekends. There is also metered street parking, which can be tough to get on week days, but is pretty available on weekends. If in town for a few days, or if looking for a worthwhile stop while passing through, this museum is definitely suitbal for persons of all ages.

The New York State Museum features a comprehensive display of minerals, along with a extensive exhibit on the World Trade Center Terror Attacks on 9/11, along with many interesting exhibits on birds, nature, the Adirondacks, and very complete exhibits on New York City, including an old 8th Avenue Subway Train.

It is not too overwhelming, and can be seen in 90 minutes to 2 hours.  Do not miss the 4th floor carousel, which is an architectural masterpiece and can be boarded for a ride as well.  Also, the New York State Library is very fascinating with much on local and state history as well.

Has a very nice gift shop and many good restaurants are nearby.  All of this free or charge!

Well worth the visit, especially on a rainy day!  Closed on Mondays.

My wife's ancestors were some of the first European settlers to settle in North America. These people, from Holland came here to Fort Orange, they settled right here between this museum and the Hudson River. The museum had a special on the excavation of this early 1600's settlement. It was so well done! The museum is vast, it's free! We parked on the road out in front. I have to say these four UGLY gigantic buildings across the street - What city planner wanted "The Empire" in Star Wars for a motif!? This is maybe the ugliest city I have ever seen. Anyway, the museum is great!
Fantastic museum with a huge variety of exhibits. Top notch. We went in expecting to get through in an hour or so, but ended up spending 4 hours. Very informative.

Based on previous low rated reviews I wasn’t sure what to expect but was pleasantly surprised.  My husband and I enjoyed our visit.  The museum was not dark and dreary as some stated.  It is small, which I liked.  We spent about an hour there.  We found many exhibits interesting. Growing up in the suburbs of NYC, we found the old subway train nostalgic and the 9/11 exhibit emotional. Many families were there since there was a special fossil activity for children.  I recommend visiting this museum.

We always enjoy visiting the NY State Museum, from the vast selection of exhibits, children’s play/ learning room, cafe & the top floor carousel, there is always more than enough to see & do to capture the interest & attention of my young son & his mom too! We highly recommend visiting here!

I love museums and this one is definately worth the visit. It's pretty large, so even though we have been there 3 times in 2 years, there's always a reason to go back and more to see. It's definately not as modern as some of the other state museums I've been to, but it does a good job with everything specific to New York. It has a very moving tribute to 9/11 and the first time we visited we spent quite a bit of time at that exhibit. On our 2nd visit we noticed a 9/11 construction site trailer that had become a memorial, but it was located on the opposite side of the museum (maybe for purposes of space). Be sure not to miss that as it's very moving. My daughter was looking for dinosaur exhibits and there isn't much in that catagory, but some interesting and educational extinct wildife exhibits including a reconstructed Mastodon.
The train car that you can walk through on it's platform really brings you back in time, and the history of immigrants and life in New York back at the turn of the last Century is my favorite part, complete with examples of old buildings & tenement housing, and store fronts and restaurants that are set up as if you are peering into a window through time. 
The gift shop is top notch, but we always seem to miss the upstairs cafe since it has limited hours.
We love this museum and if you visit in summer there is a beautiful memorial fountain to all New Yorkers who served in WWII outside that is very large and spectacular.
My only wish is that there could be restaurants nearby.

name: USS Slater DE-766
reviews:
I would just like to praise the people at the USS Slater and all of the hard work they have done on the ship.  We have been here three times, and today was our fourth.  I go to school at nearby Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and always look forward to seeing the Slater again year after year.  Our tour guide Tom was the best anyone could ask for, knowledgeable and entertaining and makes you really interested in the history of the ship, and we thoroughly enjoyed exchanging Navy stories with him from people we knew.  The tour began with a video introducing the Slater and why she was built.  After the regular tour was over, he then went ahead and gave us a tour of the engine rooms, which was a real thrill -- something I had not seen on any of my previous visits.  It's a testament to everyone there that even though this ship is now 75 years old, it still looks exactly like it did in 1945 -- what a tough little ship!
Overall, I cannot recommend the USS Slater or Tom highly enough!

DThis afternoon, August 9, 2019,  our 10-member family group visited the USS Slater. We ranged in age from 77 to 6.  We had been there about 10 years ago and the experience is much improved.  The tour lasted a little over an hour and the engine room tour about 45 minutes.

This is a restored Destroyer Escort which gives a very realistic picture of the conditions in which our sailors lived and fought carrying out their role in defending shipping of supplies to Britain during World War II. The ship is in excellent condition and there was ample time for hands on activity.  

Our guide, Priscilla, was a wonderful narrator.   In particular, she was easy to understand.  She spoke clearly and slowly enough that I, who am hearing impaired, had no trouble understanding her.  She offered the opportunity to handle objects.   She solicited and answered questions thoroughly.  She was very pleasant and patient with us as we navigated the ship.  

Some members of our group also toured the engine room and enjoyed that visit, as well..  Charles, the guide for that tour, was happy to answer questions and gave detailed explanations that interested our family members.  He, also was friendly and outgoing and clearly enjoyed his subject matter.  

I would recommend this trip for any people who are interested in WW II history and, especially, the War in the Atlantic.

So satisfied with touring this icon. The history told by our guide Evan was interesting and I don’t doubt for one minute his accuracy with all the fascinating facts he knew by heart. The ship is in terrific condition thanks to hundreds of volunteers that must be very passionate in keeping this important piece of Naval History alive. 
I agree this is the number on attraction in Albany. 
Ernie and friend from AP

Took my Grandchildren ages 6 to 25 any they learned alot. Really opened they eyes to the naval part of WWII.  Some of them had many questions about this huge part of history, which is barely taught in school today.
The tour guide was very knowledgeable and very enthusiastic about his topic.  He was able to answer all questions that were asked.  He was also very patient with my kids.

Like one TA reporter below, I have been on many boat/ship tours like this before, and this was probably the best experience of all.  Even though we did not get the best of guides, somehow the scale of the ship in particular put the whole Atlantic/Pacific German/Japanese WW11 into full perspective;  200 men cooped up in this small tub, the sea furiously trying to capsize them at tmes; being possibly torpedoed at any moment, or being the subject of a kamakazie attack from the air  -  life could be short!   
Or perhaps it was the excellent state of preservation of the ship, or the little minor details you do not seem to get on the bigger ships, like the mess arrangements,  or the large variety of armamaents you can sit on/manouver/play with the guns, including the shells - again, unusual on such ship tours.   Must be good for kids too.
WELL worth $8, and putting aside 1-2 hours if you are in/passing through, or near the town.

All ages will love this tour. Very engaging volunteers & a fun trip. You don’t need to be into military things to enjoy this tour, but is a bonus if you are.
Very hands on for kiddos as well. 4 & 6 year old had a blast.

We decided to visit the USS Slater and see what it was like for the men out at sea during World War II. It ended up being a great experience filled with so much that we had never thought of. Our tour guide Greg, ended up adding to the experience for being such an enjoyable guide and person to talk to. He was very knowledgeable about everything in the boat and was very professional and friendly. it shocked us even more we we learned it was his first day there. Overall loved it and was so happy we went.

name: New York State Capitol
reviews: Recently, I visited for the third time the NY State Capitol and it is just a wonderful place that can be revisited every few years.  Also, I have visited the Nation's Capitol as well as several State Capitols and I can attest that this one is even more impressive than our Nation's Capitol.  The free, one-hour guided tour is highly informative and, depending on the tour guide, you can get different historical information and information relating to the decorative elements of this unusual, tasteful and  ornate Capitol.  My recommendation is to make reservations if you visit   during the weekends, but  you may be able to get on a tour if there are "no show" reservations.  Regarding Albany, it is simply a shame that there is no plan to rescue entire neighborhoods built after the Civil War to accommodate the number of craftsmen that moved into the area to build the Capitol.  There is exquisite residential architecture that is just simply wasted!

This is an absolutely beautiful building to tour featuring magnificent architecture and sculpture and art. There lots and lots of stairs to several floors, so wear appropriate footwear, but we'll worth the climb!

The New York State Capitol tour offered free four times each day from the Visitor Services store on the main Concourse of the Empire State Plaza provides the very best historic tour of  unsurpassed art, stone carvings and 19th century architectural design in the Western Hemisphere.

Went on the Ghost Tour of the Capitol around Halloween 2019.  The building has hand carved animals and people throughout.  The marble floors and great halls are elaborate and covered with depictions of historic events and times. The Ghost stories were an added benefit.  Learning about the spirits that are rumored to travel freely around, greatly enhanced the lure of the stately structure.
Plan ahead because the building is not open on weekends, but if you sign up in advance, you can have a tour anyway. The building is amazing and a feat of architecture. Really a must see!

You can sign up for guided tours but I walked in for the DIY tour. Plenty to see and learn from self guided placards & no need to wait for the group! Good short stop on the way to NYS Museum & NYS Plaza.

We took the self-guided tour and, had we scheduled a guided tour, would likely have a 5 star review -unfortunately, we did not have access to the chambers.  The building is outstanding and is one of the most important state capitols given the legacy of law and leaders who have passed through it's halls.  Just walking through the portrait gallery in the upper hall tells a tale of Presidential history.  Easy street parking and good spots to eat in the vicinity.  If it's cold, take the underground mall passage to the New York State History museum which is OUTSTANDING!

We visited this place on October 8. There is visitor parking under the plaza. After the security check we went to the lobby were you can sign up for a guided tour.
You can do a self guided tour but you will not see the senate.

name: Washington Park
reviews: We came here for a quick walk to get some fresh air, and while it was maybe the wrong season (too cold for nice weather or flowers, and without the pretty fuss of the Christmas season), the park was still spacious and well-maintained.  There were still other people going for walks or runs, and there are bridges over the bodies of water, plus benches for people to sit and enjoy the scenery.  In warmer weather, it looks like it would be a lovely place for a picnic.

Capital Winterlights display starts promptly with the 12 days of Christmas, but no one tells you so you don't realize it until you see the 3 French hens & 4 calling birds! Good variety of holiday displays and worth doing. Enjoyed walking the route in the daytime and driving at night. Cost $20. They need to tell people to turn off their headlights! Washington Park is smallish, so not as nice as Bright Nights at Forest Park in Springfield, MA.

I really am so lucky to be able to have a park that has so many events to go and walk to for free. Between the free park musicals in the summer, tulip festivals, and farmers markets, it really is a gem. Even just taking a walk around the park and ping to the dog park that is there is cool.

I walk through the park on a regular basis. It is always different. In the Spring there is the Tulip Festival, which is spectacular. During the summer there are several different festivals, ethnic and otherwise. Also, during July and August, in the park we have Park Playhouse with musical comedies which are very professionally done. Now, arrangements are being made for the holiday Festival of Lights, which is quite beautiful. Finally, at various times during the year, there are running and walking races. What a wonderful way to enjoy the park!  Washington Park is an asset to Albany and the surrounding community.

Washington Park is a beautiful urban park that resembles parks designed by Frederick Law Olmsted; however, he didn't design this one.  Designers of this park copied Olmsted's ideas.  And, they did such a good job that many people mistake it for an Olmsted-designed park.

The park is located in Albany’s Washington Park Historic District and is surrounded by many historic buildings designed by famous architects. 

Washington Park Lake is one of the main features.  There are paths that lead to it. During my visit, there was a man fishing on the bank opposite the Lake House.  

Washington Park Lake House is the primary landmark in the park.  It had features from the Spanish architectural style – terracotta and terrazzo composite.

The park had many memorials.  I visited several of them.  

The park is good for walking on streets that allow vehicles as well as footpaths.  Crossing over to the other side via a footbridge was popular with several walkers I saw.    

One can also drive on several roadways in the park.  

During my visit, I did a combination of walking and driving.  

This park was a very relaxing place to be.

This was my final bit of sightseeing before heading home from vacation.

I rate Washington Park at 4.50 and recommend a visit.

If you found this review helpful, please click THANK below.

name: Schuyler Mansion
reviews: Wonderful tour with an emphasis on Alexander Hamilton - tour guide was very knowledgeable! I highly recommend this tour!

This is a beautiful restored early American colonial home. Being an Albany resident I was fascinated to learn George Washington and Ben Franklin along with many others were once guests. Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr both have been through it’s doors and President Millard Fillmore even got married here! 
It is a key piece of local and even National history that is truly worth exploring. Our guide was very knowledgeable and did a great job.

I was caught off guard at the beautiful interior - the wall covering was unique, the spindles on the stairs and the authentic furniture pieces from the Schuyler family. Pictures were allowed - the rooms had wonderful light from the windows. You could ll but see a dance on the 2nd floor area. I appreciated the knowledge of the family shared by the tour guide until she began speculating on Schuyler's motivations regarding actions. I am so glad this mansion was preserved and with authentic pieces! There is a small free parking lot beside the mansion and restrooms within the visitor's center. The only way to enter the mansion is by taking the tour.
Don't miss the twelfth night celebration (Saturday near Epiphany--January 6). Great way to round out the Christmas holidays--plenty of music, food, spirit and entertainment.

I reserved space weeks in advance for our party of six for a focus tour of the Schuyler Mansion entitled "When Alexander Hamilton Called Albany Home."  And the tour was spectacular!  We got a thorough tour of the Schuyler Mansion, but the in-depth narrative for this longer-than-usual guided tour was on Hamilton and his connection to the Schuyler family and the mansion.  It was in the home's beautiful front parlor that Hamilton was married to Eliza, daughter of the home's owner, Philip Schuyler.  And there is so much history -- Hamilton-related and otherwise -- imparted on this rich, interesting tour.  I don't know how many guides give this tour, but our guide -- Jessie  -- was special.  Informative, engaging and thoroughly knowledgeable of her subject matter, Jessie could not have been a better guide through this gorgeously curated, fascinating home.  The mansion is itself a great historic site and worth a visit.  If you can, reserve a space on the limited Hamilton focus tour; you will be treated to an extra layer of the home's fascinating history.

We stopped by the mansion at 11am on a Sunday and found ourselves with a personal tour of the Schuyler mansion because there were no other visitors. Our tour guide was absolutely wonderful - I wish I had caught her name to thank her here. She spent about an hour with us in the mansion telling us all about Philip Schuyler and his very interesting family, walking through the rooms that most of the major Revolutionary war players would have also walked through.

The mansion is located in one of Albany's not-so-great neighborhoods; don't let that discourage you from visiting. There is a parking lot and it's very easy to find - I just wouldn't plan on wandering around the neighborhood after. There is a small exhibit in the visitor's center (it'll take you maybe 5-10 minutes), including a model of what they think the grounds looked like in Schuyler's day - definitely try to check that out before or after your tour.
Wonderful tour with an emphasis on Alexander Hamilton - tour guide was very knowledgeable! I highly recommend this tour!
Beautiful house and terrific, inexpensive tour. Would definitely drive here, good parking lot.  Tour guide answered lots of questions from the group.

Despite their website saying they are open..... THEY'RE NOT, on a Sunday.

We went there this afternoon, and they are closed. They were setting up for a 2pm concert, and genuinely apologized that the website is not correct. They've only been aware of the mostly for several months, and can't seem able to correct and update. Pitiful!!!!

We stopped here after visiting the Albany Institute of History and Art.  Ian was our guide and he knew everything about the house and family. Very interesting stories of how Albany and its residents took part in US history

We recently toured the Schuyler Mansion and learned a great deal about the families that were influential in the development of Albany. Our guide shared information about the Schuyler and Van Rensselaer families as well as details about family life in the house. Our tour guide was excellent! The mansion has been restored with a combination of original furnishings and reproduction materials. This a hidden gem in Albany and does not get the attention it deserves!

name: Albany Institute of History & Art
reviews: We found this museum on a miserable rainy day and were delighted to explore pieces from its diverse collection, an exhibit on a remarkable local artist and a phenomenal exhibit on the Hudson River School. There's a little cafe and a beautiful museum shop. It's been in downtown Albany for ages, and it's a wonderful way to spend a few hours. A real find.

I was able to catch the exhibition on Vivtiorian Dresses.  It was well annotated. I enjoyed  reading about how these ornate dresses were constructed. Of course, the exhibition of Hudson River School of landscape paintings was  fantastic.

We went initially to view the costumes worn by the gentry in the 1800s which was excellent, but found so much more to visit. An Egyptian section complete with mummy, a large art collection, a section on commerce and trade in early Albany, statues and more, including a nice cafe and small museum book shop. Free parking when visiting the Museum.

A great museum- not to big, not to small, but JUST right! Wonderful works of art representing the Hudson valley, beautiful sculptures, and a cafe with good coffee and macrons.  Nice way to spend a few hours in Albany.

This museum is small but definitely worth the visit. It cost us $8 each as we had a AAA card discount. Loved the exhibits on the Schuyler sisters. We learned some interesting details like how one of the sisters was a spy during the Revolution. Also, it was interesting to learn more about the duel between Aaron Burr and Alexander Hamilton. There is even an ancient Egyptian exhibit with mummies. The Hudson River School art is a highlight with scenes from places we know like the Adirondacks and Lake George-simply lovely. Definitely plan a visit if you have a few hours to enjoy these treasures.

After a hectic business trip it was a relief to find parking near the AIoH&A and enjoy a local immersion for two hours. World class exhibit on the Schuyler Sisters with Alex Hamilton relics; an unknown folk artist; local painter; children's book diorama artist; sculpture; ancient world; gift shop & cafe, I bookmarked this place for return visits when next in Albany. Lots of school programming going on all around us.
The museum has an interesting exhibit but is small and unsensational.  Maybe worth an hour and a half on a rainy day.
Have been here several times over the years for the special exhibitions.  We tend to get the passes at the library.

name: Crossgates
reviews:
On vacation in the Greater Albany area for several days, I had a Shop ‘til You Drop day.

After checking out of a hotel on Wolf Road, I went to the Northway Shopping Center first.  I’d shopped Colonie Center in October and wanted to shop somewhere different on this trip, so I went to the Crossgates Mall.  It had been several years since I’d shopped there.

Some of the anchor stores have changed since my last visit.  The larger stores now include Lord & Taylor, Macy's, and JC Penney.  Other well-known stores include Forever 21, Old Navy, the Apple Store, J Jill, Burlington, Aeropostale, Famous Footwear, DSW, Gap, Pandora, Dick's Sporting Goods, Wilson’s Leather, H & M, Oakley, Hollister, Zara, American Eagle Outfitter, Vans, Best Buy, and a Disney Store to name a few. 

There were over 35 restaurants ~ everything from Wendy’s, Johnny Rocket’s, China Max, Dunkin’, and Starbucks to Nathan’s Family Deli, Uno Pizzeria & Grill, and Texas de Brazil.  

Crossgates Mall also has an 18-screen IMAX Regal Cinema theater as well as two Hilton hotels.

During my visit, I concentrated on Lord & Taylor because the closest one to me is in the Prudential Center in Boston and is difficult to get to.

The first item I liked was an Adidas Track Jacket.  It had features I really liked: classic styling with a geometric cut, comfortable raglan sleeves, side zip pockets, baseball collar, and rib-knit neck, cuffs and hem.  Originally $75.00, it was on sale at $56.25.  That was only 25% off.  It was not marked down enough for my liking.

There was a roomy drawstring-closure tote bag in a subdued grayish willow green at $30.00.

Nearby, I was drawn to the attractive display of Chanel’s Chance fragrances.  All four seemed to be floral-based. 

At the Jewelry counters, I saw a pair of amethyst earrings; but, at $650.00, they were somewhat pricey.

In the Shoe Dept., I saw some pretty strappy shoes.

Then, I went to other parts of the mall.

Old Navy was having good sale with a lot of items marked down 50%.  

Rue 21 had a 25% off sale.

I really enjoyed shopping at Lord & Taylor and browsing at several other stores.

I rate Crossgates Mall at 5.0 and recommend adding it to one's Albany itinerary.

If you found this review helpful, please click THANK below.

Whenever I am in the Albany area, I always include a stop at Crossgates.  First, as a large mall, I get a nice walk in simply wandering around.  Easy on/off from thruway and plenty of parking.  A good variety of options: movie theater, food, and stores.

Visited Crossgates last week whilst on a trip from the UK to watch our son graduate from Siena College.

Great variety of shops on offer, and reasonably priced.

A classic mall on the outskirts of Albany, NY between the town of Guilderland and the City. Nearby SUNY Albany. A varied mall that still keeps a good amount of activity and a lot of decent, well-run store. A decently sized movie theater and tasty food court as well.

We went there today because we were looking for after Christmas specials. We enjoy Crossgates, but do not go often because of the distance. Lots of stores...I enjoy looking at things before buying. Our kids love the Lego store and the 5 Below store. We also love the escape room!

I'm in my early 30's, been going here my whole life and it's a great mall, don't get me wrong, BUT... it's just not the same and it lacks the variety of stores that used to be there. For example, other than Williams Sonoma there's no kitchen/food store when there was Gourmet Chef before, no toy store anymore (other than the Lego store), and no book store. There also used to be kid friendly, hands-on science related discovery type stores that were fun to go into and good places to find different and fun gifts. But on the positive side there are at least 6 "anchor" stores, a solid food court plus a variety of other actual restaurants, and a lot of quality businesses. There are also things to do like escape rooms, a huge movie theater, and arcades so it can be a full day or a great place for a date night. Bottom line, I'll be back and I'll continue to hope there will be a bit more variety next time because things do change.
This is a very nice shopping mall. They have plenty of stores to suite everyone's needs. Also have excellent places to eat and drink.
This is a great mall to shop at. I do windowshopping here and also get things from starbucks. I also eat dinner here occasionally.

name: Erastus Corning II Tower
reviews: Corning Tower opened in 1973 and is the tallest building in upstate New York. Take the special elevator to the 42nd Floor Observation Deck for spectacular views of Downtown Albany.  On a clear day, you can see 3 states!  There's no charge for admission.  This is a must!!!

The Corning Tower has a free observation deck that allows visitors to take in gorgeous views of the Helderberg Escarpment, Hudson River, and the Capitol District.  Access the elevators from the Plaza Level and head on up!
This building is located in the Empire State Plaza a must stop when visiting Albany.It is next to the State Museum You can miles from the enclosed observation deck. The best thing its free.
We missed going here the first day as they close at 4pm.  So we went up the next day.  Beautiful panoramic view of the city.  We also liked that it was free.

This is quick and free and a must if in the area.  

With a little assistance from a nice guy managing the area, I hopped on the elevator that was sitting there ready to take people up to the Observation Deck.  It was Thursday afternoon and I was the only one taking the elevator up.  It's a quick ride.

Once at the top, besides the security officer, there were only three of us.  It was all indoors behind glass.  The views are terrific.  You can see the buildings below, and the mountains off in the distance.

As I walked up to the elevators they opened to take me back down.  Motion sensored?  And the ride down was quick.

A great experience that was free and line-less and quick.

Located in the heart of the Empire State Plaza, the 44-story Corning Tower is the tallest building in Albany, and the observation deck on the 42nd floor offers expansive views of the Hudson River Valley, Corning and its environs, and the plaza itself.  The tower is named after Erastus Corning, a former mayor.  A fast (16 mph) elevator, free of charge, whisks you to the observation level. You will not get a 360 degree view, as the west side has no windows. Other attractions within walking distance fro the tower, adjacent to the plaza are the New York State Museum, the very gothic Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, and the Egg, a performing arts venue at the northeastern corner of the Plaza. Many buildings on the edge of the Plaza, as well as in the Tower, are offices for New York State government. Numerous pools and fountains are located in the Plaza.  Make a day of it if you have the time.

This is the tallest building around and when the observation deck is open on the 42 floor, you get great views of the surrounding area.  There is interesting art work on both the Plaza and Concourse level of this building and it is part of the Empire State Plaza complex.

It's just a thing to check off on your Albany trip or to kill to e if you're early for the capital tour. In a world where buildings are routinely taller than 40 floors, the Corning tower is not a novelty. The view was beautiful, we looked, and that was all. Extra star for the fast ride up- moderately entertaining

name: Times Union Center
reviews: Great sight lines, easy to get to, just off the interstate and easy parking in two parking garages within a block. Great place for a concert or ice hockey!

Great night out with Veterans at the TU enjoying the our favorite monster trucks and team. Redesign of the facility allows customers to now enjoy a huge enclosed front entrance with plenty of extras. Great seats, fun and venue! Thanks VetTix!
What a wonderful show. The light show and the music is outstanding. The Christmas theme was great. Wonderful musical talent plus the Orchestra uses some local musicians in the program.

Many of us were kicked out into snow while waiting for Uber or other rides. Show ended at 11PM & wanna be cops working for Times Union Center kicked us out at 11:21 into the snow & stating they wanted to go home. It’s a shame after spending $200 on tickets plus drinks at $13/beer they couldn’t let us safely wait inside for our rides. Very disappointing that they can’t treat other humans w/ respect. Kane Brown put on a wonderful show too bad it ended on a negative note.

Noah's show was fresh and thoughtful.  His command of multiple languages and accents was absolutely hysterical! His ability to find humor at the edges of cultural differences and his ability to find the common human threads of funny was tear inducing.

Went to see cirq de solei which was a 
 is so poorly designed, i wont be back for anything. Really! I cant believe someone over the age of 6 designed this, and how did any adult sign off on this?

I went with a dear friend to see Celine Dion here.  While she put on a great performance and the seats were good and comfortable, it is the facility and parking that caused an issue.  Being from out of town and limited knowledge of the area the parking while close really isn't marked very well.  There were police that didn't really help the traffic congestion. Once inside there was a funnel into three or four metal detectors, followed by the actual entrance.  It all seemed unorganized.  Now I am not sure if this happens for every event as this is the only one that I had been to. Like I said the arena was nice, it was just the parking and entrance that was an issue.

We saw Celine Dion there and she was incredible. The venue was ok as getting in was a little crazy with the long lines for security. The floor seating was comfortable although it did seem like a smaller arena.

name: Palace Theatre
reviews:
My earlier review of April 10, 2019, was 5 star.  Not this time around.  I was denied entry to a concert because I brought along a compact camera that is considered "professional" and therefore forbidden.  It did not have a zoom lens or a large sensor.  It was slightly larger than pocket size, but the lens can detach from the body.  Evidently, this makes it a "professional" camera.  

I have brought this same exact camera and lens to several prior concerts at the Palace Theatre.  I have always been careful to dim the LED display to not interfere with those seated nearby and to limit the photos.   

Of course, I missed the usual sea of camera phones held high recording stills and video continually throughout the concert, many boasting image resolution higher than my camera.  (And, this is before photo "stacking" that can boast resolution further.) Maybe it's time to revisit the policy for all camera devices.  

It's a small consolation that the Palace is way behind Albany Times Union and NYC Beacon Theatre (among other venues) in booking name concert talent.  And I did not have to sit in those soiled-looking, thread-bare seats.

The Palace is nothing short of a gem from Albany's glory days. It speaks beautifully of a bygone era of big theaters hosting big name stars. The acoustics are very good, even in the highest seats, the staff is helpful and polite and even local parking is pretty good. Performers may disappoint, but The Palace never does.

This is a very nice theatre, but not for a rock concert! Saw several people being thrown out because they wouldn’t stay near seats. Lighting on stage was nice. I would have loved to know you can’t get near stage before we purchased tickets because we would have traveled to another city. The staff was nice though.

Drove down to Albany to see Jerry Seinfeld perform... After all this time it seems he is still in his prime nonstop laughs.. the palace is really nice with a broadway look and feel to it with all the blinking lights and posters.. seating was really good and offered a nice selection of beers.. offered free parking as well.. definitely recommend seeing a show here..

Unlike most arenas (e.g. Times Union) and modern theatres, the space between seat rows, or "pitch", in the orchestra section is quite generous.  This leaves plenty of room for dancing in place to the music.  Beginning around Row K, the rows of seating are fairly banked, making it easier to see over those with big hair or headgear.  $4 soda, water, and candy is a refreshing change to Times Union high prices.  This theatre is the upstate equivalent to the NYC Beacon Theatre, in terms of fine acoustics, music acts and professional staff.

name: The Egg
reviews: Not knowing what to expect, we decided to catch a show at the Egg. What a pleasant surprise. We were in the smaller of the two theaters - maybe about 500 seats. Great acoustics and not a bad seat in the house. Very intimate concert setting. A bonus is the on site parking which is only $5.00. It’s in the same building as the concert halls and the elevator from the garage takes you right to the lobby of the theater. (Take the exit for the concert venue and the “visitors garage” is right there) Overall great experience.

The Hart Auditorium is an awesome place for concerts. We got to enjoy Harry Connick Jr. and it was like being in a club. He and his band said they enjoyed playing at smaller venues and seemed to be having fun.

After seeing over 50 shows, I can safely say The Egg is a wonderful venue to see live music. Having the option of two separate venues is also a plus for those lesser known and/or acoustic leaning acts that work better in a smaller more intimate setting.

The Egg hosts an interesting variety of shows and events.  It's worth a visit just for its unusual architecture and as a part of the Empire State Plaza.  There's a great view from any seat in either of the two theaters, and no problems with hearing. Parking is easy and reasonable in the lower parking decks, but only during nonworking hours of the State, such as nights and weekends.

I've attended many performances in the confines of either the Hart or Swyer theaters, and are so happy with them.  Unless you are seated on the very edges of either theaters' seating, there isn't a bad seat to be had.  Parking is convenient with an underground location in the form of the Empire State Plaza's V lot.  Being sheltered from the weather, you can easily leave your coats in the car for the short walk to the elevators to the Concourse level.  The only criticism of the venue I can think of is you can only ride elevators up to the theaters.  Crowds can overwhelm the capacity of the elevators for awhile, especially when the shows let out, but it's a minor inconvenience at most.
Really nice venue to see a band.  Seating was excellent and sound was great.  Affordable to all.  There is plenty of street parking after 6PM as well as the underground parking garage.

Very Very small venue. If you want a beer you will wait in line over 30 minutes, if you have to go to bathroom you will wait over 20 minutes . You also can't drink the beer in the venue. Way not worth it

Not knowing what to expect, we decided to catch a show at the Egg. What a pleasant surprise. We were in the smaller of the two theaters - maybe about 500 seats. Great acoustics and not a bad seat in the house. Very intimate concert setting. A bonus is the on site parking which is only $5.00. It’s in the same building as the concert halls and the elevator from the garage takes you right to the lobby of the theater. (Take the exit for the concert venue and the “visitors garage” is right there) Overall great experience.

We wanted to like this building but the tour was boring.not for kids. The shape of the building is interesting and thats all. also not happy that I didn't know where to take a photo in front of the building. TBH, maybe they disclosed on the tour but my kids wanted to die from boredom so we had to exit early.

The Hart Auditorium is an awesome place for concerts. We got to enjoy Harry Connick Jr. and it was like being in a club. He and his band said they enjoyed playing at smaller venues and seemed to be having fun.

After seeing over 50 shows, I can safely say The Egg is a wonderful venue to see live music. Having the option of two separate venues is also a plus for those lesser known and/or acoustic leaning acts that work better in a smaller more intimate setting.

name: Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller Empire State Plaza
reviews:
this is right across from the state museum which I think is the highlight of Albany
if you want to walk up to the Carousel floor you have to do it form this plaza
interesting modern art
we liked the yellow one the most
ducks swimming in the pool
a solid 20 minute walk

The layout is breathtaking and yet every little nook is functional. A great playground for kids, beautiful memorials for both fallen veterans and another for fallen police and corrections officers, a unique and wonderful civic center, the majestic Corning Tower with the Agency buildings and the incredibly long Swan Street building, plus an ice staking rink, wonderful sculptures, and room for two stages: it's all done in breathtaking marble. But the real treasures are all underground: the Concourse is lined with simply unbelievably great works of art, including but certainly not limited to an original Jackson Pollack oil from his yellow phase.

This plaza has something for everyone.  First, architecturally, it is absolutely beautiful.  Lined with interesting agency buildings, the cultural education center and the egg, it sports a very large fountain/reflecting pool and plenty of walkways. The corning tower has an observation tower on the 42 floor.  Food trucks, vendors, farmers market booth provide food and collectibles.  There was even a CPR demonstration going on the day we were there.  Pick out something for lunch and sit on one of the many benches available and enjoy.

I researched and planned this visit for weeks but, when I got there, I found the access to elevators was blocked... on a saturday! The undergroud concourse had great artwork on display but I was very disappointed to miss the Plaza... it was a beautiful day too! Walking around the place, I got a feeling of "Life After People"...almost deserted...

The plaza, which dates from the era of the Rockefeller governorship (1960s), is an example of mid-century futuristic design, with The Egg, a concert venue, dominating the eastern side of the plaza.  The State Museum is at the south end, a somewhat nondescript building given the magnificence of the Egg.  Below the plaza level is a mall with shops that are frequented by government workers and tourists alike.  It's very quiet on weekends, and most of the shops are closed, but the upper level is blissfully uncrowded and a great place to wander around and enjoy the beauty of the surroundings.

this is right across from the state museum which I think is the highlight of Albany
if you want to walk up to the Carousel floor you have to do it form this plaza
interesting modern art
we liked the yellow one the most
ducks swimming in the pool
a solid 20 minute walk
Breathtaking. Rockerfeller obviously did not want to be outdone by his contemporaries from the Soviet era.

Empire State Plaza was conceived by Gov. Nelson A Rockefeller after a visit by Princess Julianna of the Netherlands. He was embarrassed by the dilapidated buildings around the State Capitol and wanted to build something more reflective of the state's wealth and importance. Construction lasted from 1965 to 1976 at a total cost of almost $2 billion. ESP consists of 11 state office buildings with more than 11,000 employees. The tallest building is the Corning Tower (44 floors) with a great observation deck.  The most unique is The Egg (performing arts center).  All of the buildings are connected by a series of underground tunnels and concourses. At street level, the buildings surround a huge reflecting pool.  There is a Visitors Center on the concourse level (with a gift shop) offering free guided tours seasonally or you can explore on your own.  There is plenty of parking nearby and several restaurants.  Definitely worth a visit -- especially the Corning Tower Observation Deck.

name: Albany Pine Bush Preserve
reviews:
My visit to the Albany Pine Bush Preserve started at the Visitor Center soon after its 9:00 AM opening.

A plaque near the entrance shows that the Albany Pine Bush Preserve was declared a National Natural Landmark in 2014 by the U.S. Department of the Interior’s National Park Service.

Inside, there is a cancellation station for those who participate in the Passport to Your National Parks program.  There are two stamps to attach in the Passport.  The first is the conventional page stamp for site.  The second is a local sticker for the preserve with a drawings of blue lupine and the Karner Blue Butterfly.  The cancellation stamp reads:
Hudson River Valley NHA – the day’s date – Albany Pine Bush Preserve
The NHA stands for National Heritage Area.  The Hudson River Valley NHA extends from Saratoga Springs down to the New York City area.

The Visitor Center had a lot of exhibits.  I walked around to all the exhibits.  They included facts about the rarity of an inland pine barren and topics of protection of habitat, human history, restoration, geology, and ecology.  Many were interactive.  I noticed that youngsters in other parties really enjoyed those.

I enjoyed the excellent, informative video titled “By Prescription” that explained how they maintain the habitat there.  I learned what a controlled burn was, how they set up for one, and how they conducted one.  And, with all that preparation needed, conditions would be right for such a burn only a few days a year.

I learned that the preserve encompassed over 3,300 acres and is one of the largest of the 20 inland pine barrens in the world.  It was formed about 10,500 years ago when Glacial Lake Albany drained. 

The preserve is home to the amazing amount of 1,500 species of plants and animals, including the endangered Karner Blue Butterfly whose life cycle depends on the wild blue lupine.  I learned where the name came from.  The butterfly was first identified and described by novelist Vladimir Nabokov.  It was enlightening to learn that he was also an entomologist, a scientist who studies insects.  Karner is a hamlet within the Town of Colonie and located half-way between Albany and Schenectady.  It was there that Nabokov first spotted the butterfly.

The Karner Classroom, down the hall from the main exhibits in the atrium, had a number of hands-on exhibits and activities to turn visitors into scientists.  There were samples of soils, seeds, snake skin, and more.  There was a microscope for an up-close look at things.  There was activity booklets to test one’s knowledge of what one learned and a machine to help one check the answers given.  I participated almost every activity there.  I enjoyed learning about the different types of soil there, the bark on trees, and what a snake skin looked like when magnified.

The gift shop, although relatively small, had a lot of things for sale that included T-shirts, sports caps, postcards, pins, coffee mugs, prints, refrigerator magnets, puzzles, small toys, some jewelry, crafts by regional artisans, and lots of books on nature-related subjects.  Prices were reasonable.  

Just as I finished buying a few things in the gift shop, the very strong T-storms in the day’s forecast arrived and turned the lovely mostly-sunny day into its direct opposite.  The sky opened up with a couple of very heavy deluges over a half-hour period.   Several other visitors and I were trapped for awhile.  The rain altered my plans to trek at least one of the trails that day.  I returned for a brief trek the next day after a full daytrip to Schoharie attractions.  

In short, the exhibits and activities there are topnotch, and the preserve is one of the earth’s rarest habitats.

I rate the Albany Pine Bush Preserve at 5.0 and highly recommend a visit for some easy trekking and to learn a few things.  

I also recommend setting aside about 3 hours for this attraction, splitting time between the Visitor Center and the trails.

If you found this review helpful, please click THANK below.

While Visiting our Daughter and Future Son In Law this past weekend, I made a reservation for us to go on a Snow Shoeing hike at Albany Pine Bush. The Preserve is located just outside of Albany and encompasses over 3000 acres of a Nationally recognized Landmark; specifically the Sand Dunes. The Discovery Center is extremely informative with many exhibits showing the diversity of this State Park.  Additionally they have many miles of Nature Trails that go through the park in many different sections. One of the trails incorporates an area that has the Karner Blue Butterfly which is listed as an endangered species. They also offer many programs for young children, families and adults alike. Which is what brought us here; a Snow Shoeing hike led by Sarah. The experience was amazing and we have already made plans to return for other events in the future.

An interesting nature preserve of sand that is host to the endangered species of butterfly known as the Karner Blue butterfly. The preserve, itself, is one of the largest inland pine barrens in the world. There are a lot of great hiking trails through the area, and an interesting center that educates you about the history of how the preserve was formed, and of the wildlife that benefits from living there. A must if you are interested in ecology, preservation and a rare inland sandy pine barren.
Easy paths, a few routes, and a nice opportunity to get out in the woods close to the City.  And postings with information for those interested in what they’re seeing , both fauna and flora.
Went to the discovery center to learn about pine bush preserve and then went for a hike around the trial. Interesting terrain in the middle of Albany. Fun day with kids
