If you found this review helpful, please click THANK below.

The visitors center was amazing.   You can rent a backpack with a laminated map and scavenger hunt pictures.   There is also a set of binoculars and a magnifying glass to get the true experience.   There are many trail options for shorter or longer hikes.  My kids had many questions that were answered by the interactive visitor center.  It was really a wonderful stop.

Easy hiking some sloping hills but overall pleasant and easy hike, fun for kids lots of placards and a small museum. Sandy soil so no mud. Definitely use DEET because there are ticks unfortunately, which is basically the only down side. Highly reccomend

name: The Stephen and Harriet Myers Residence
reviews: I have been very involved with the Stephen and Harriet Myers Residence and the Underground Railroad History Project. It is an historic site that is growing from the ground up. The story of the Residence and of Stephen and Harriet Myers is inspiring and amazing. It is a story that surprises as it is not well known. In addition to that the many involvements of young and old in the development of the project is remarkable. It is a treasure in the community and promises to get even better as time moves on!
Its a diamond in the rough. An insight on the brave and courageous couple whose life-saving work was accomplished here.

This site (that serves as a museum, historic site, and community-based heritage center) provides a wonderful introduction to the activities of individuals like Stephen and Harriet Myers, who contributed to the Underground Railroad in the Albany area and beyond. The information shared helps visitors build a more comprehensive understanding of the contributions of many men and women who supported people seeking freedom from enslavement and who contributed to the abolitionist movement. Learning about programs at the site (community gardens, teen programs, tours) is inspiring as well!

A top history location to visit while in Albany.  The best part of the tour is the docent giving a verbal description of life for people in the Underground world.  They answered questions that made clear the life of a slave traveling; slaves did not necessarily travel at night with a lantern.  This museum is open after other Albany museums close; so visit other museums during the day, then visit this museum from 5PM to 8PM, then go have dinner.

This small "museum" is located in a home that is currently in an unfinished state of rehab.  It is dedicated to understanding the role of Albany is helping freedom seekers on their way through the underground railroad.  Once finished, it will be a gem.  Be aware that there is not much parking and this a a 3 story home with no elevator.

The Myers Residence was wonderful!  It's a small building and does not take long to complete a tour of (about an hour total) but is filled with neat bits of history.  The volunteers do a wonderful job telling a general story of the underground railroad efforts and the Myers' role in it.  Actively being restored to present the house more as it was.  You must stop in if you're in Albany and want to do something meaningful!

Great historical tour, I forgot the lady's name that conducted the the tour but I left with greater knowledge about the underground railroad. I also ended up debunking misconceptions I had about the underground railroad previously given to me by sugarcoated history lessons.

We were welcomed into this historic home and given a personal introduction into the museum by the curators. The  introduction included a description of the museum as a community enterprise as well as the history of the house and a view into Stephen and Harriet Myers lives as they lived in this house.  The museum is small, not taking more that an hour to view but well worth taking into your itinerary .

We were in Albany for a long weekend and found this site. It is a work in progress, but the owners were kind and gracious. We arrived near closing time but the owner welcomed us in and sat with us in the living room to tell us the history of the house. He and his wife have done a lot of research into the Underground Railroad and linked this location to publicized meetings of vigilance committees. Very interesting history! The nonprofit also does a significant amount of outreach and educational programs with youth in the area. This is worth a visit. (Especially if you’ve gone to see the other famous house in the area, the Schuyler residence, which family kept enslaved persons.)

Me and my classmates visited the Stephen Myers house this past Saturday and it was amazing, the preservation of such a historic relic is a beautiful sight to see as well as the feeling of the history surrounding you is amazing.

My wife and I made a visit to the Stephen and Harriet Myers home a must see during our trip to Albany for the holiday weekend. We enjoy learning about the local African American history wherever we travel.  The home is a time capsule full of rich architectural detail and is very impressive when you remember the time period.  Our tour guide was Mary Liz and she was friendly and very knowledgeable about the Myers and other local African American abolitionists in the Albany area. 

The home has undergone and continues to go through extensive restoration  to preserve its rich history.  During the tour all I could think about are the conversations that took place within the walls to help escaped slaves and fight for basic human rights. As gentrification continues we are losing valuable monuments that celebrate the lesser known freedom fighters and the work and sacrifice they made at the risk of losing everything including their lives. 

If you visit Albany, NY stop by to take in the history of the Myers!

name: Chester A. Arthur Memorial Tomb
reviews: The Albany Rural Cemetery is a fantastic place to take a walk on a sunny afternoon. There are many paved pathways, and the cemetery allows pets on leashes. There is so much history as the cemetery was planned in 1840 and opened in 1841. It is interesting to learn how they carved and moved some of the massive obeliisks that are throughout the cemetery. It is definitely worth visiting if you are interested in Albany's history.

I was prompted to give a review so I couldn't resist the laugh of sharing that  it has been a year since I was last in the cemetery and I'm reasonably certain that it no different then any other of the multiple times I've seen it in my life and would bet it is the same as it looked when it was new and the President was first laid to rest. Don't expect much, it isn't like Kennedy's tomb in Arlington.

Finding Arthur's grave is easier if you have a map of the cemetery.  It is on the corner of one section and is noticeable because of the flagpole beside it and the huge angel.  Other family members are buried in this same section.
Nice stature of the 21st President in the United States of America. It’s well constructed and recommended
We really wanted to see this gravesite and searched for about 30 minutes before we found it.  It was worth the time.

Visiting the Albany Rural Cemetery is worth it to see the history of Albany. I'll admit, Arthur's grave was an afterthought because we came to see Peggy Schuyler's grave and that of her father, Gen. Philip Schuyler. When we found out Arthur was here, we made a point of seeking him out too. Maps are provided at both entrances and it is easy to locate the graves. The cemetery is beautiful and the gates are open until 7 p.m.
Small Albany rural cemetery. Grave is very easy to find. It's not a large tomb like a lot of the late 18th century presidents.

Love to walk in cemeteries.  So much history.  Albany Rural has many dignitaries buried there, besides Chester Arthur. John boyd Thatcher, Mayor Corning and many more. Tombstone carvings done by stone masons many moons ago, unbelievable!!!! Also the veterans burial ground a must for our fallen soldiers. Much history, great walk, also tours offered occassionally. Call office for dates and times.

name: Huck Finn's Playland
reviews: Heck Finns playland was originally known when I was a child as Hoffman’s playland. It was a vital memory of my childhood living in the capital district. It was closed down and reopened in a different location as an adult. This place is beautiful for kids. It’s like a small fair for kids up to age 12 or so. Rides fair food and of course you cannot miss the fried dough. Oh and I didn’t mention that the adults can go shopping for furniture next door at Huck Finns warehouse

Small amusement park with ‘classic’ rides well-suited for the under-10-years-of-age-crowd.  All of the basics are there, including a small roller coaster perfect for toddlers.  The most remarkable thing about the park is the terrific staff.  All of the ride operators (and ticket agents) are warm, friendly, and sensitive to the little kids.  Great services and support.  Truly worth a couple of hours.

Ok so I’m dating myself, here, but I first remember this Playland from the 1950’s when it was on Rt 9 in Latham and owned by the Hoffman family. It was pretty much the only fun thing to do in the Capital Region when I was a kid. Fast forward to its current
Reincarnation as Huck Finn’s Playland, this place is amazing. It is exactly the same as it was when I was a kid. It is immaculate,  and the rides are operated by clean cut adorable and polite young adults. My granddaughter and great nieces and nephews had a blast. One very cool thing is that it’s also close to Druthers and all the restaurants in that area, so after an hour or two of riding, you can practically walk to any number of great places to eat and drink. 
Kudos to Huck Finns for preserving this important part of our community and doing it in such a classy way.

Just very nice place. Clean and tidy. People who operated the rides were all polite and cared about you having fun. Small local peace of capital district history. Honestly they can barely be breaking even. Almost too good to be true. Reminds me of Catskills Game Farm that should of been helped to stay open. That too was a treasure. My kids and now one of my grandchildren have been here. Nice job to whom had an eye to make this happen. Thank you HuckFinn owner ...nice place!

This is the best place to have fun with your children or grandchildren.  I took my children to Hoffman's Playland for years, and I was so happy when the rides were moved over to Huck Finn's Warehouse.  It's a great place to laugh and have some fun.  I plan to revisit this summer as soon as it opens.

name: Nine Pin Cider Works
reviews: There is a decent amount of parking on the side road and across the street of the cidery. There is a great deck/porch area for the summer. Huge variety of ciders and not overwhelmingly sweet. I didn't try all of them, but the earl grey tea was my favorite. It was not overly tea-like. There is a slight hint of tea, but there is a clear apple taste to it. I have had other tea ciders and they were too heavy on the tea. My favorite by far!

I have high cider standards, so always walk into a new cider spot with a little trepidation. The staff here is fantastic and super friendly. They offer 4 and 9-cider flights, and have 11 of their offerings currently on tap. We opted to share a 9-flight and set out on figuring out which of the 2 to not try, with staff help. We ultimately settled on our 9, only to be surprised to have a mini-taster of the other two when we got our batch. Super nice! The ciders themselves were great. The base was flavorful and fresh - one of the better base ciders I've had around. We got into their flavored ones next, and while all were pretty good, there were definitely some stand-outs. The ginger was packed with ginger flavor and some heat, really fantastic. The cranberry was nice and sharp and very flavorful, and the spiced cranberry was even better - balanced with some chai and mulling spices. The peach was solidly good too. Nice assortment of bottles, cans, and other merch. Definitely seemed a popular spot, and I can see why. Check it out!

my wife had a sampler of four different ciders, while I went straight to a glass of their ginger cider. Everything we tried was good (she let me take a sip of each of her ciders) but the ginger was definitely the best. We ended up buying some to take home.

Be sure to note the rose mural on the building next door.  It was painted by the owner's father years before the cidery opened.

Went to their event to carve a pumpkin and get a pint of cider with my daughter after work and we had a great time. The choice of pumpkins was great, they had newspaper down on the tables and all the cutting tool you could ever want to just sit and cut and carve your masterpiece. The original cider is my favorite so I had that, love this place and their product

Our family of 3 spent a bit of our afternoon at Nine Pin. We each ordered a flight of 4 types of hard cider and shared a cheese & meat board and chicken basil pot pies. In my opinion the ciders all tasted about the same, except for the ginger cider. I was happy that the food was gluten free! There are board games to play and the atmosphere is carefree and casual.

name: Discover Albany Visitors Center
reviews: Whether you know Albany well or not, this place should be your 1st stop to get info on city attractions & happenings.  The woman who helped us had a wealth of knowledge on what to do, where to park at different attractions, & some history of the city.  If you're a fan of the Hamilton musical, the Schulyers are a big part of this city with a special exhibit running at the Albany Institute of History & Art.  Also their mansion is where Alexander married Elizabeth.  Albany has colorful murals & dog sculptures at various spots around the city so the staffer gave us maps pertaining to them if we wanted to seek them out.  The dog sculptures are now indoors for the winter so we only saw 2 but it would be fun to see these whimsical creations around the city in the spring.  The visitor center itself has artwork displayed & a historical exhibit.

We were walking to a restaurant and happened by the Heritage Visitors Center.  At first it seemed like a typical welcome center with booklets etc.  Then we noticed a room off the hall near the bathrooms.  WOW! What a cool museum.  This is a real gem, a wonderful place!  I highly recommend visiting.  To my surprise, such a great museum had no charge.  They also have a cute gift shop.

Stop in at the Albany Visitors Center which has all the information one might want when visiting the capital of NY. The staff is well-versed and helpful. They have many brochures and handouts as well as a terrific self-guided walking tour. Also there are exhibits on early life in Albany and a comfortable theater where we watched short movie on the history of Albany.
I wandered through the visitor center's displays.  They have a historical view of the history of Albany and the neighboring Quackenbush house.  It's free and gives good background info for the city.

Whether you know Albany well or not, this place should be your 1st stop to get info on city attractions & happenings.  The woman who helped us had a wealth of knowledge on what to do, where to park at different attractions, & some history of the city.  If you're a fan of the Hamilton musical, the Schulyers are a big part of this city with a special exhibit running at the Albany Institute of History & Art.  Also their mansion is where Alexander married Elizabeth.  Albany has colorful murals & dog sculptures at various spots around the city so the staffer gave us maps pertaining to them if we wanted to seek them out.  The dog sculptures are now indoors for the winter so we only saw 2 but it would be fun to see these whimsical creations around the city in the spring.  The visitor center itself has artwork displayed & a historical exhibit.

As probably for about all of these visitors Centers it is the place to find infos about what to be seen. THe clerk was friendly and provided lots of infos that actually made a difference in our tour of Albany. A good ressource...

Finding this place is challenging and kind of like a well kept secret.  We thought we knew what we were looking for, and we were wrong.  But once we were there, we realized we had not allotted nearly enough time for our visit.  They not only have basic visitor center information and a small gift shop, but they have a very interesting museum on the history of the area.  We could have easily spent an hour or more here.  Note: when going through, start to the left.

Parking is a difficult and expensive all over town, and this area is no exception.  Do yourself a a favor - go down Spencer Street, and take a right on Montgomery to the end.  There is free parking under the highway ramp for the Visitors Center, and it is very convenient.

We were walking to a restaurant and happened by the Heritage Visitors Center.  At first it seemed like a typical welcome center with booklets etc.  Then we noticed a room off the hall near the bathrooms.  WOW! What a cool museum.  This is a real gem, a wonderful place!  I highly recommend visiting.  To my surprise, such a great museum had no charge.  They also have a cute gift shop.

name: Empire State Plaza Convention Center
reviews: Lack of signs can get you lost at the convention center and occasionally parking can be a problem as well.

It's a huge office complex housing the NYS Museum, the Plaza (open air with seating, fountains; the Egg performance auditorium (check for pricing).  Call NYS information number for events scheduled, which are almost always family friendly.  The Concourse houses McDonald's as well as an upscale restaurant;, drugstore and a gift shop (I think?); artwork all along the way.  Leads to NYS Capitol Bldg., which is also interesting.  Kids can run all along the way!

We've had occasion to attend numerous events at the EPSCC in downtown Albany and also have attended events in several other cities.  The concourse seems to be lacking compared to what is offered in numerous other areas and parking can be a challenge if your event is during business hours.
I don’t travel much so I had no idea what to expect. I was impressed with the cleanliness and enjoyed my time there.

Great place for a walk on a sunny day. And when the weather is not as lovely, you can head underground. In winter, ice skating on the plaza is one of the most romantic things to do in the Capital Region. While in summer, the Capital Concert Series, which includes a spectacular fireworks display on the 4th of July, draws huge crowds.

Free street parking after business hours.
what a great venue.. cold, windy, snow and sleet.. everything you could want for an outdoor concert...lol but well set-up, managed and a gorgeous venue in a killer town.. kudos!!
Come here for beautiful views of the city, looking east over the Hudson River Valley. Locally there are state buildings, the Egg, and a museum.

Love this place for the walking we can get in during inclement weather. Food area held many treats for us to enjoy.  Home co op Friday for lunch at 130pm
Although we spent too much time at the museum we arrived underground and found this place for lunch.
Healthy food we were in heaven! Due to the lateness of the day we were able to get two chicken wraps and a bag of chips along with hot drinks.
Would go here again as the clerks were friendly and had fresh healthy food there.

Loved jewelry vendors during the holiday season lining the center aisles of the walking areas. 
Will travel here again next year..

name: Lark Street
reviews: Lark street has a lot of cool little shops and eateries that are fun. Parking isn't always the easiest as something to be aware of.

A walk down Lark Street used to be a visit to Greenwich Village of old. But many of the restaurants and shops have closed, and the feeling isn't there anymore. There are some treasures so don't totally avoid a visit, but you need to walk the street from Washington to Madison to find what you want. You can get coffee, burritos, ice cream, etc, and you can also pop into the shops on the way. But I miss many of the shops of the past.

There are some nice places to eat here and very nice wine restaurant, however, eat and go.  Parking is atrocious and the kids are interspersed, between locals and vagrants.  At night, it turns into a giant street party with drunks everywhere.

Lark Street is the place to get coffee, shop for cool accessories, and had decent food. Come here during Lark Fest in September and all the stores and restuarant will have a stand up for you to check them out or eat their best food.
This a cool oasis in the heart of New York's Capitol!! Great little spot to stroll, see the shops and grab some food. Their are neat blocks of old houses on every street. Fun to do.
Visit Dominic’s Caramello Candy and Coffee.  You won’t be disappointed.  Very clean and great selection.
Not many choices in the commuter city of Albany, this is one of the few, lotsa places to eat and drink, but a little crusty around the edges.
Old buildings, parking poor, question whether it is safe to walk around in the evening, not a highlight of any city

name: C.H. Evans Brewing Co.
reviews: Lots of choices of their own draft beer at the bar in the restaurant,  plus a few others.  Haven't had a loser yet.  Menu is good, too:  better than standard bar sandwiches/wraps/burgers plus entrees that go above and beyond.  They offer tours of the brewery, growler purchases/refills. They handle special events nicely.  Can get very noisy when the place is full - beware if you have hearing problems.

Love love love the varying beer choices here. It is a must stop when we travel to the capitol region. The beer menu has a few staples that are always available and it also has seasonal offerings. If you are a beer lover it is a must !! Enjoy!

Love love love the varying beer choices here. It is a must stop when we travel to the capitol region. The beer menu has a few staples that are always available and it also has seasonal offerings. If you are a beer lover it is a must !! Enjoy!
An out of the way place to relax and unwind. The wait staff is friendly and friendly.The beers were pretty good and you can get a sampler so you can see what you enjoy the most.

For twenty years Evans Brewing Co has been my go-to place for out of town visitors, gatherings of friends, receptions, and solo or family dining.  Always enjoyable, as staff is professional and attentive, seating is comfortable and not crowded, something is available for all (vegetarian and meat-eater; adults and child; alcohol or not).
Wait staff was very good but my Spouse meal was under cooked and terrible. Nothing Fancy,just Burgers and pasta. Only average across the board,plus beer was actually luke warm!

This history of the building is told by its working parts still visible above the bar and restaurant. Very interesting to my engineer husband. Visited on a food tour and sampled a few beers and cider. A busy place.
This place has a really good brewery atmosphere. The burgers and sandwiches are also amazing. Obviously the beer was really good. Highly recommended.

name: Albany Indoor Rockgym
reviews: Its not so expensive either but bring cash or your Amex card. This place is fun for adults and kids alike. They have 2 rooms for wall climbing a indoor caving system and a zipline. The cave is like a maze its quite fun they have built rooms and obstacles in the cave for exploring.  My friend and I will go there just for the cave sometimes and just explore it for a few hours its pretty good exercise.  If you want to climb and are new to it the guys there are really helpful.  They have shoes and gear you can rent they will help you with it and belay you and take you through different exercises if you want to do them.   If you want to do the cave wear comfortable clothes but form fitting if you have loose hanging clothing it might bug you and below knee pants or longer many be more comfortable because you are crawling around a bit. They will also let you leave for lunch and comeback without paying extra just let them know. Theres also a pizza place next door so you can get take out and eat at the gym they have tables inside. No lockers rooms but they have one big bathroom is you want to change there.

Its not so expensive either but bring cash or your Amex card. This place is fun for adults and kids alike. They have 2 rooms for wall climbing a indoor caving system and a zipline. The cave is like a maze its quite fun they have built rooms and obstacles in the cave for exploring.  My friend and I will go there just for the cave sometimes and just explore it for a few hours its pretty good exercise.  If you want to climb and are new to it the guys there are really helpful.  They have shoes and gear you can rent they will help you with it and belay you and take you through different exercises if you want to do them.   If you want to do the cave wear comfortable clothes but form fitting if you have loose hanging clothing it might bug you and below knee pants or longer many be more comfortable because you are crawling around a bit. They will also let you leave for lunch and comeback without paying extra just let them know. Theres also a pizza place next door so you can get take out and eat at the gym they have tables inside. No lockers rooms but they have one big bathroom is you want to change there.

This place looks like nothing from the outside but offers quite a bit on the inside!  The two rooms full of rock climbing walls offer varying degrees of difficulty and also interesting things to look at (paintings, "rocks" sculpted into interesting shapes).  We're relative beginners, but have noticed many advanced,experienced climbers return again and again.  They offer spots to climb harnessed to a rope (for which you need a partner), and spots to climb without a rope.  The floor is rubbery and soft, for safety's sake.  Also for safety's sake, beginners get a thorough free lesson, with a trainer who will stay with you as long as you feel you need it.

The reason why we have repeatedly returned to this place rather than the other nearby rock-climbing place is its unique (at least, in this area) extensive labyrinth of pathways through the indoor "caves."  My teenage daughter, who had completed a demanding course in outdoor caving, was worried it would not be interesting or a challenge, but found it to be challenging and a lot of fun in very different ways from outdoor caving.  From several different entrances, cavers make their way through intersecting passageways that are often pitch-black to get to several spots of interest:  slides, a room of lights and mirrors, a hammock, and most notably, a zip line.  Because the passageways are actually behind and inside of the rock walls, they stretch from floor to ceiling and around three walls, so you can actually get a moderate muscular and aerobic workout (although not as strenuous as with the rock climbing) from walking or pulling yourself up hill and through spaces of varying sizes.  (The caves are NOT for those who are uncomfortable with the dark or with small enclosed spaces. On the other hand, I have seen kids afraid of both, prompted by the rewards of the interesting spots within, to gradually overcome both fears here.  Adults who are significantly overweight or who have very broad shoulders may not fit through all spaces and are not even allowed in the caves; every person who desires to enter them must pass a brief test where they have to get themselves through a roughly three-foot-long tunnel of the size of the smallest area they would encounter inside the caves.  [That is what we were told; those who actually went into the caves and believe they explored every single pathway never found anything that tight.]  Also, because of the potential for using the zip line [which goes out of one cave, across a large open space, and into another cave, just below high-ceiling height], all cavers are instructed as to how to properly get into and adjust a harness.)

I and the dozen or so people I've spoken with who go or have gone there once or regularly believe that Albany Indoor Rockgym is a fantastic place to visit on a cold or rainy day.  For roughly $8 to $15 - depending on your chosen activities and the hour - you get to spend from one to several hours (There is seldom a time limit) challenging the rocks, exploring the caves, and almost certainly making a few friends.  The only negative we've all found is that certain staff members can be extremely moody and not very understanding.  (This was the only thing keeping this place from a five-star rating.)  Others are wonderful, and even the moody ones will be more pleasant as they get to know you better, and are still wonderful instructors.

A couple of little rules and comments you should know about before going with children:  Unlike some other places which don't allow climbers to go without a parent until age 13, this place allows children as young as 10 to rock climb and cave without a parent as partner.  Children younger than 10 MUST have someone with them 18 or older who is actually accompanying them as belayer (holding the rope) or through the caves.   Anyone under the age of 18 must have a parent sign an insurance waiver, either in person or printed from the gym's web site, signed off site, and brought in by the child.  Although it is not necessary for the person accompanying young children to be a parent, the person signing the form MUST be the parent, as I learned when I tried to bring children of friends.  I would strongly recommend both the rock climbing and caving to adventurous, energetic kids age 7 and up, as well as to teens and young adults.

Just passing through Albany and thought we’d try something different. This place was tons of fun and both Matt and Steve were super helpful “showing us the ropes!”  Can’t wait to do this again. Would recommend for couples, families, or a group of friends. Thanks again Matt and Steve!
Love the indoor rock cave and climbing! Kind and helpful staff. Excellent place to visit on a day that is too hot or rainy.

We came for the well maintained rock climbing.  However, upon discovering the intricate and unique cave system, we spent all of our time exploring.  This facility is designed and maintained by professionals who are familiar with climbing and caving.

We just had a "lock in" overnight with Troop 26 from Fort Drum, NY.  I honestly thought the boys would tire after a few hours, but we literally had to pull them out of the caves and off of the walls!  The caving system was a BLAST (even though I got a little "stuck")!  It was pitch black in most places and tight, but I was laughing all of the way through it.  The Scouts had a great time on and in the walls and ceilings!  We will definitely come back!

Spent the afternoon here caving with my daughter who's 11, husband and friends. This was our first time here. The owner was very friendly, helpful and awesome with the kids. The kids spend four hours exploring the caves while the adults tired after two hours. The great part about this place is that you can bring in your own food, stay all day or leave and come back later in the same day. Cheap all day family fun indoors. That's something that's hard to find these days. Would absolutely go back and recommend this place to friends.

name: Albany City Hall
reviews: Albany City Hall opened in 1883.  Romanesque style architecture with a 202 foot tower.  Only municipal carillon in the country.  Added to National Register of Historic Places in 1972. One of the most notable occupants was Erastus Corning 2nd who was mayor for 41 years (1942-83). Corning Tower in the Empire State Plaza is named for him.
Another beautiful style of architecture that contrast with the French Renaissance style  State Capital and modern style Rockefeller plaza

I came across this building as I was taking a "self-guided" tour of downtown Albany. The City Hall is a really neat place...old-style architecture in a grand way. The security guard welcomed me inside, where I took a quick tour of foyer and the exhibits up front. Very impressive! This is a free stop, and worth your time.
Loved viewing this beautiful building from the outside during my 2 days in Albany. I walked by it on my way to my meetings and on my way back to my hotel.

While driving we found the Albany City Hall. It was a massive building with a clock at the top of the tower. It was beautiful!

The inside was attractive as well. There were two kinds of stairs, one at the left and the other on the right.

There was an exposition on that day.

I enjoyed admiring this structure.

It was worthwhile to see!

name: US Route 20
reviews:
As others have said, Rt. 20 is one of the oldest highways running across the country east-west.  Most of it is now bypassed by highways.  Starting in Boston, super-highway Route 90 runs parallel - tolls, heavy truck traffic, etc., but much faster route.  

We live in an historic mansions on Rt. 20.  This 2.5 mile stretch running through downtown Albany is a local 4-lane road with a 30MPH limit, lots of lights and a good place to get a speeding ticket.  Starting from the east at the Hudson River and coming up out of the Hudson Valley, you will travel between rows of brownstone buildings from the 19th century (some earlier), some very good restaurants and then views of the New York State Empire State Plaza with "The Egg" performance center and dramatic administrative buildings.

If you have some time, a visit to the Plaza is highly recommended.  Look for signs for public parking under the plaza.  In good weather, above ground is this half mile long plaza with the wonderful State Capital bilding at one end, The NYS Museum at the other, several marble-covered administrative buildings plus the Corning Tower (tallest building between NYC and Montreal) and the mushroom-like performance center "The Egg".  Running parallel below ground is a very long corridor flanked by the giant paintings of Governor Rockefeller's collection, some of the 1960's greatest modern art. The Museum is a favorite for kids.  Finally, if you can schedule a tour of the State Capitol building, you will view one of America's greatest pieces of architecture.  Near the Capitol is the NYS Education building with its massive colonnade and many other historic buildings.

Continuing up Madison Avenue, you cross Lark Street, an area with some fine bars and eateries.  Now, out of the valley, Washington Park, designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, will be on your right.  You then pass by many historic mansions followed by the College of Saint Rose.  Finally, there are some decent eateries and bars on the left before Rt. 20 becomes Western Avenue.  There is another mile or so of city homes with worthy architecture before things become more commercial.  You will also pass by the State University of Albany before you get to the connections with superhighways Route 90 (east-west Boston to Buffalo) and Route 87 (south-north New York City to Montreal).

After several more miles of suburbs, then out into rural Upstate New York.  If you continue on this four lane 55 MPH road westward, recommended stops are the tree farm in Esperance (summer), Sharon Springs (the 19th century summer retreat for NYC Jews not welcome in Saratoga Springs), historic Cherry Valley, and then on into the Finger Lakes region with its many delights.

Cool, we get to review a road :)

Actually this one is worth talking about. In Albany as Western Ave it leads from several suburbs from I-88 on one end to the Route 155, the Thruway and Northway all the way downtown to old Albany. There are many restaurants, malls and daily necessity  shopping along the way. There are less traffic lights than you would think for this type of road but you will have to stop often enough.

The aforementioned  Rte. 155 is a great connector to Central Ave, a similar road in town  and the convenient Washington Ave extension

Route 20 is a great way to cross the entire state west/east if you prefer going through towns. Not sure where is heads westward, but it does continue into Massachusetts all the way to or near Boston   

For what it is, you have to give to the five star rating here.

Rt 20 runs from Mass to the west coast, but the drive from Albany to Cooperstown is especially nice. Not too nice in the winter as the snow can blow across the road and pile up. The views from Duanesburg west to Rt 80 are terrific. On a clear day around Cherry Valley you can see well into the Adirondacks.

One of the country's oldest and longest interstate highways, US20 in Albany is within one of the oldest cities in the US, founded in 1609. From there it goes west through the suburbs to rolling hillsides, farmlands, past lakes and villages. Because it travels into parts that have grown along with the population, traffic too has grown. It changes from cityscape with heavy traffic to suburbs, where the traffic thins, to the more rural areas where you can drive more leisurely. Traffic changes at various hours and the road changes too as it gets farther out from the city. Enjoy the scenery and the beauty of Route 20.

On a summer road trip, we chose to take US 20 from I-81 into downtown Albany rather than use I-90 and pay its tolls. We had the sun behind us since we were driving in the late afternoon. Summer weekday traffic wasn’t all that bad until we actually got into Albany. We enjoyed viewing the rolling hills in the countryside. Far to the east, we glimpsed the Empire State Plaza of downtown Albany, the Hudson River Valley, and the Berkshire Hills beyond. The grand vistas were unexpected. If we ever pass this way again, we’ll be sure to take the same route.
great sightseeing road so much better than using an interstate and you get to meet interesting people along the way and discover amazing local eateries

We made a point of driving from Albany to Cooperstown along this scenic drive, based on TripAdvisor recommendations and mentions in other travel materials. But it's just a country road and not especially scenic at that. There was the occasional church or ice cream stand, but it doesn't wow.

Rt 20 runs from Mass to the west coast, but the drive from Albany to Cooperstown is especially nice. Not too nice in the winter as the snow can blow across the road and pile up. The views from Duanesburg west to Rt 80 are terrific. On a clear day around Cherry Valley you can see well into the Adirondacks.

name: Shaker Heritage Society
reviews: Historic farm, settlement, nature trail, graveyard tells the story of the birth of Shakerism in the New World. Small museum, tours, walking, trails, and special events. Easy to get to, hard to forget.

We enjoyed the film and the very helpful docent. She encouraged questions and shared interesting information. The meeting house was very large and there are many buildings on the grounds. We also visited the cemetery.  Parking and admission are free!

The Shaker Heritage Society is a gem located near the Albany Airport.  The history of the Shakers is very interesting, and the grounds are lovely.  A visit to the summer and fall craft fairs is a must for me, as is a visit for holiday shopping in the Meeting House.

Historic farm, settlement, nature trail, graveyard tells the story of the birth of Shakerism in the New World. Small museum, tours, walking, trails, and special events. Easy to get to, hard to forget.

We enjoyed the film and the very helpful docent. She encouraged questions and shared interesting information. The meeting house was very large and there are many buildings on the grounds. We also visited the cemetery.  Parking and admission are free!

Not a large village or building left as land has been sold off to the airport. Most buildings in a decayed condition and not able to enter. Some information via video at the startand some animals to see outside.

I  have been to 2 other shaker villages one in kentucky and one in
 Pitsfield Massachuttes
this one needs a lot of capital to restore the old existing structures
it is a shame since this movement started here.   Worth noting their inventions includes the circular saw, prepacked seeds and furniture. oh by way it is free but they ask for a donation    what I did was to buy a souvenir to help them out   it is a gem in the rough

This was the first Shaker village in the US. The main building has been restored and open to the public. Besides the building they have a 20 minute video and a gift shop. The rest of the village is standing, but in disrepair waiting for restoration.

name: Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception
reviews: Best to Google the Cathedral website and go when they have guided tours for all the info about the history and art.  Park in the State lot behind the Cathedral, free after 2pm M-F, free on weekends.

This cathedral was built in the mid ninetieth  century by Irish immigrants. It survived the construction of the Empire State Plaza, when some 40 blocks of downtown were razed.  The building is lined with stone, has two very large steeples and a beautiful interior. Parking is free on the weekends and late afternoon during the week.  Gorgeous walnut pews and stained glass windows, origin to the church.  Definitely work a stroll through and a place to quiet meditation and prayer.

Beautiful old classic Cathedral.  Attended some beautiful weddings there.   Park there on the weekend and also visit the NYS Museum without moving car.  Also State plaza and memorial monuments outside.

When we arrived at the cathedral we thought it looked closed but on going round the front the door was open. It was empty so we had it to ourselves. It is a beautiful, spiritual place. The stations of the cross are expertly carved. The whole building has an impressive feel.
Well preserved inside and out. Easy parking. Handicapped accessible. Wonderful architecture . Every religion should visit (not only Catholics)

I had a day in Albany unexpectedly, so I took Uber downtown from my hotel, and really enjoyed walking around experiencing this very cool historic city. The Cathedral was the capstone of my visit, such a pretty and serene church! I really enjoyed taking photos of the statues and beautiful ceilings, highlighted by the ornate stained glass. A very special prayerful experience! Highly recommended!
Attended a beautiful wedding here and loved the 19th century architecture! Gorgeous building and stained glass windows!

We did a self-guided tour of the cathedral on Saturday, May 25, 2019.  The interior of the church is very striking and the height of the vaulted ceilings reminds us of the European cathedrals (Koln, Cologne, Strausbourg) that we have visited in the past.  The carvings that serve as capitals for the columns are very detailed.  During the time we were inside the church, a local family was celebrating a baptism.  The outside of the church is beginning to show wearing away of its brown stone walls.  Some of the exterior is draped in protective cloth to prevent pieces of the blocks from breaking away.

name: Park Playhouse
address: Madison Ave. cor. New Scotland Ave.
reviews: Great show! Open air summer theatre. Outstanding, talented student actors and professional performances. Highly recommend and will go again next year!

We've been attending Park Playhouse performance for many years since living in Albany. It is a wonderfully professional organization providing excellent performance in Washington Park.  Recently we attended the play Chicago and it was fantastic.  The acting, music, dancing, singing, orchestra, was all excellent.  We enjoy being entertained in the Park on a warm summer night.  A wonderful atmosphere in an open air environment.
Great show! Open air summer theatre. Outstanding, talented student actors and professional performances. Highly recommend and will go again next year!

Once again the Park Playhouse put on a magnificent production.  The play was cast perfectly and the choreography was great.  Everything about the production was first class and the audience loved it.  The next show is "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying".  I wish I were going to be here to see it.

Many a year, our family has attended the Washington Park Playhouse. The outdoor theatre is by far one of our favorite things to do each summer. Being able to bring a picnic, sit and relax before the show, people watch as the sun sets, is truly a favorite.Our only complaint is we wish the Park Playhouse would do more family friendly musicals. 
Thanks for the shows!

Very nice production of the Damn Yankees in a very lovely park. We were taken aback by both. The only flaw if any is not to stray too far away from the amphitheater for there are some skunks lurking. Very well done all.

Fantastic professional organization bring adult and children musicals to Albany in fresh air seating. Seats available for purchase but they are just plastic lawn chairs so frankly you'll find it more comfortable to just arrive at least an hour early and do lawn seats that are graduated so there's no bad seat in the house. Awesome that you can bring a bottle of wine and picnic with you. Long lines at intermission for bathrooms so plan accordingly. Those handicap they offer close parking or others pay just $5. ( free parking avail on street). Absolutely something you should enjoy every summer as a home town treasure.

name: Fort Orange Brewery
reviews: Came today with our family and friends. The beer is good, especially the stouts. They have a good, unique deal called The Gauntlet...10 samples for $22. However when we went to order, the bartender was very snippy, rolling her eyes that she had to make another Gauntlet that day (they had been open for 30 minutes). Very rude. So many great beer places in the area to come here and put up with rude service for ordering beer on their menu.
Cool vibe and set up and staff awesome. Just nothing jumped out. Not their fault as everyone has their own choice. Will try again if in area!

Great little brewery, note, not a restaurant so do not expect a meal minus some snacks.  The beers were nice, in that it was not 101 IPA versions.  Had a really nice brown ale along with other styles (see picture).  We were there on a night with trivia which was pretty fun, free flight for winners of first half and $25 prize for winning (dominated and got both).  Great stop if you are in the area!

Quaint and fun brewery with a good selection of beer - all tasty. They are pet and kid friendly. There is normally a food truck parked out front and snacks at the bar. All and all a fun place to have a few rounds.
A typical small brewery with quite a few beers. Not the best that I have tried, but a friendly and cheerful place to have a few.

name: The Irish American Heritage Museum
reviews: We were out and about and had 30 minutes until closing so decided to drop in and check it out.  There are a few displays but the best part of this museum to me was the library in the back room! One could spend a couple of hours back there doing some serious research. If you plan a visit, half an hour will do for the exhibits, but plan two hours+ and bring your research list if you plan to work in the library.

I stopped in here because I had some spare time after lunch one day. It is an interesting place, although it really only warrants about 10-15 minutes of time. (I did not look at the library, which others have said is very impressive.) The volunteers there are very friendly and knowledgeable, and fun to talk to. I wold recommend this place if you are right in the area, or if you are Irish. Otherwise, I would probably skip it.

The Irish American Heritage Museum is especially appealing the week before St. Patrick's Day when I visited.  They have a very interesting art collection of Michael Augustine Power O"Malley through March 2nd, along with a very fascinating research library with some great picture books of Ireland.  Will attend a lecture tonight on Irish Genealogy 101 which should be very enlightening and educational.  This week, they have many interesting lectures. Museum is walkable near the Holiday Inn Express Hotel in Downtown Albany, NY on Broadway.  The staff was very welcoming.

If you are Irish or have any interest in Irish heritage, please make the trip to come here; it is a fascinating museum.

This is a very small museum in the historic downtown area but they have a lot of interesting Irish artifacts that you're unlikely to see elsewhere.  Very pleasant staff!  Have dinner or lunch at the nearby Olde English Pub on Broadway and you may hear some Irish music too - call Olde English for information.  No parking - use a taxi or Uber.
Totally enjoyed walking through this path of immigration history! If you’re in the area, definitely stop in!
Great museum for anyone Irish or who has an interest in the Irish. Right now they have a great exhibit about Fr. Patrick Peyton and his Hollywood ministry.
This is a very small place with a limited variety of artifacts, however it was fun to visit and the staff was great.

I stopped in here because I had some spare time after lunch one day. It is an interesting place, although it really only warrants about 10-15 minutes of time. (I did not look at the library, which others have said is very impressive.) The volunteers there are very friendly and knowledgeable, and fun to talk to. I wold recommend this place if you are right in the area, or if you are Irish. Otherwise, I would probably skip it.

name: American Italian Heritage Museum
reviews: Stopped here with my Italian wife on our way through Albany. We got to the door only to realize it wasn't open on the day we came, rang the doorbell anyway and were surprised to be welcomed in for a tour. Received great personal attention and spent a quiet few hours making our way through the stories and collections in the various themed rooms. I'd be surprised if there's anyone of Italian descent who isn't moved, educated, and/or inspired by a visit.

We got a history lesson and tour from the Professor who was the founder of the museum. He was friendly, helpful, and knew everything! The parking was easy, museum was clean, full of so much information and so many items to view.  Small place packed with so much.. Loved it all!

We visited this small, but jam packed museum early in the afternoon on Saturday May 25, 2019.  The museum presents an intricate look into the emigration of the Italian people.  The building is a converted church with the museum taking up the main floor.  The second floor has office space used by museum staff.  The museum was originally located in Utica, New York.  the display area is broken into then major rooms with each room having a different central theme.  The docent on duty at the time of our visit was very cordial and readily engaged us in dialog.  We spent almost two hours viewing the displays.  Our opinion is that this museum is a hidden gem.

I came across this museum purely by accident when searching Google for fun and interesting things to do in the Albany, NY area with my folks, who were in town for the day. This little gem is a completely independently funded museum, operated purely by donations from members and donors, as I understand it. It is a museum devoted to the history of the Italian peoples in America, and the journeys they took to get here. It is, supposedly, according to the gentleman we spoke with, either the largest or the most comprehensive museum devoted to American Italians in the country. It appears to be kind of cobbled together in some aspects, but don't be fooled. There are a TON of artifacts and historical pieces crammed into 5 or 6 small galleries. It take perhaps an hour or a little more to go through, and admission is 5 bucks. Beware... the proprieters do not get many visitors on weekdays, they like to talk, and it is open odd hours, but if you can catch them when they are open, this is a nice little trip to make, not just for people of Italian descent, but also for people who want to learn more about this ethnic group. As an Italian American, I approve! Also, a little gift shop in the back offers some affordable memorabilia as well! Great day trip! :)

This museum is not only unique for its collection on Italian history, artifacts, and culture but offers special classes and programs for those who wish to learn more about the immigrant experience, the Italian language, etc.  We have brought friends who are not of Italian heritage, and they were delighted to experience this unusual venue.  One of my Irish-American friends found many items that related to her grandmother's coming to this country that she had not seen before.  And the museum is located in a lovely, former church which adds to the whole experience!

Stopped here with my Italian wife on our way through Albany. We got to the door only to realize it wasn't open on the day we came, rang the doorbell anyway and were surprised to be welcomed in for a tour. Received great personal attention and spent a quiet few hours making our way through the stories and collections in the various themed rooms. I'd be surprised if there's anyone of Italian descent who isn't moved, educated, and/or inspired by a visit.

We visited this museum while looking for things to do in Albany.  What a find!  The museum is small, but it's packed with memorabilia of the history of Italians in America.  And there are some very knowledgeable organization members to guide you through the well stuffed rooms.  Lots of pictures, lots of documents, lots of art work, and lots of conversation with the very friendly volunteer staff at the museum.  We would have stayed longer, but the museum hours are fairly short and we had already kept everyone there past closing time with our barrage of questions.  It was time to let them go home.

We had some friends visiting on a rainy weekend and since my wife had wanted to go to this museum for some time, decided to go.  This is because she knows a woman who has two sculptures in the museum.  All the items in the museum are donated and all the people who work there are volunteers, who like telling you about the museum and exhibits, and encourage you to join.The museum honors the Italian immigrants who came to the US and seeks to preserve their memory.  Since we are descendants of immigrants, although not of Italian heritage, we found this an interesting and welcoming museum.
